modules.title: Introduction to Research and Research Problem
topics: Introduction to research: meaning, objectives, characteristics, significance, and types of research
Steps of research and the scientific approach
Defining the research problem: definition, selection of research problem, necessity and techniques for defining the problem

modules.title: Research Design, Sampling Design, and Data Collection
topics: Research design: meaning, need, features, types, concepts, and principles of research design
Sampling design: implications, steps, criteria, characteristics, and types of sampling design
Scaling techniques: measurement scales, sources of error, tests of sound measurement
Classification and scale construction techniques
Methods of data collection: collection of primary and secondary data, and selection of appropriate method for data collection

modules.title: Data Processing, Analysis, and Hypothesis Testing
topics: Processing and analysis of data: importance of statistics in research
Simple regression analysis and multiple correlation and regression techniques
Testing of hypotheses: concept, procedure, and power of the test
Parametric and non-parametric tests and their applications

modules.title: Interpretation, Report Writing, and Statistical Tools
topics: Interpretation of research results: techniques of interpretation and drawing conclusions
Report writing: layout, steps, and types of reports in research
Introduction to statistical software tools used in business research: SPSS

courseOutcomes: Identify and define a business research opportunity
Synthesize and critically evaluate literature related to a business problem
Reflect on and evaluate research processes within a specific context
Develop argumentation and construct hypotheses based on research findings
Apply appropriate research methods and design a complete research project
Justify the use of qualitative and quantitative methodologies in business research
textBooks: Cooper & Schindler, “Business Research Methods”, McGraw Hill
C.R. Kothari, “Research Methodology: Methods and Techniques”, New Age International
referenceBooks: R.S. Dwivedi, “Research Methods in Behavioral Sciences”, McMillan India Ltd.
Uma Sekaran & Roger Bougie, “Research Methods for Business”, Wiley

modules.title: Introduction to Financial Management and Financial Analysis
topics: Financial decisions in a firm and goals of financial management
Fundamental principles of finance and the risk–return tradeoff
Forms of business organization and the agency problem
Emerging role of the financial manager in India
Analysis of financial statements using financial ratios and Du Pont analysis

modules.title: Capital Budgeting and Cost of Capital
topics: Capital budgeting techniques: Net Present Value (NPV), Profitability Index, Internal Rate of Return (IRR), Modified Internal Rate of Return (MIRR), Payback Period, and Accounting Rate of Return (ARR)
Computation and significance of cost of capital
Cost of individual components: cost of debt, preference share capital, and equity
Weighted Average Cost of Capital (WACC) and its role in financial decision-making

modules.title: Long-Term Financing and Capital Structure
topics: Sources of long-term finance for business enterprises
Concept of capital structure and its effect on firm value
Assumptions underlying capital structure theories
Net Income (NI) and Net Operating Income (NOI) approaches
Traditional position and Modigliani–Miller (MM) propositions
Leverage analysis and its implications on financial performance

modules.title: Dividend Policy and Working Capital Management
topics: Dividend policy theories: Walter Model, Gordon Model, and Modigliani–Miller (MM) Position
Determinants of working capital requirements and influencing factors
Operating cycle and cash conversion cycle analysis
Cash and liquidity management techniques for efficient operations

courseOutcomes: Critically evaluate the impact of financial decisions on an organization’s strategic direction
Identify and assess financial risks and apply techniques to manage them effectively
Explain various sources of finance and evaluate their suitability in different business contexts
Evaluate complex investment appraisal situations and understand the role of cost of capital in decision-making
Analyze strategic financial considerations in mergers and acquisitions, including company valuation
Assess a company’s financial performance and propose actionable recommendations
textBooks: Prasanna Chandra, “Financial Management – Theory & Practice”, Tata McGraw Hill
referenceBooks: Khan M.Y. and Jain P.K., “Financial Management: Text and Problems”, Tata McGraw Hill
Srivastava and Misra, “Financial Management”, Oxford University Press

modules.title: Introduction to Biological Systems and Biosensors
topics: Introduction to biosensors: principle and general characteristics
Proteins and enzymes: basic properties, denaturation and renaturation
Enzyme immobilization techniques and their applications in biosensors
Advantages and limitations of biosensors
Classification of biosensors based on bioreceptor types
Immobilization and coupling of bioreceptors with transducers

modules.title: Bio-recognition Based Sensors
topics: Principle, operation, and limitations of microbial sensors
Immunological sensors: design, principle, and application
Nucleic acid sensors and their functional mechanisms
Use of animal and plant tissue as bioreceptors in biosensors
Different types of inhibitors: principles, operations, applications, and limitations in inhibition-based biosensors

modules.title: Biosensors Based on Transducers
topics: Classification of biosensors based on transducer type
Calorimetric biosensors: principle, construction, calibration, and limitations
Electrochemical biosensors: potentiometric and amperometric principles and applications
Optical biosensors: design and working mechanism
Piezoelectric biosensors and semiconductor biosensors: construction and operation

modules.title: Applications of Biosensors
topics: Applications of biosensors in the clinical and diagnostic sectors
Industrial applications: food processing and environmental monitoring
Use of biosensors in defense and security sectors
Overview of commercially available biosensors and their technologies

courseOutcomes: State different types of bio-recognition elements and describe the fundamental components required to design a biosensor
Illustrate enzyme immobilization methods and how they are used in biosensor construction
Describe different biosensing elements and their applications in biosensor technology
Understand the classification, construction, and working principles of various transducers used in biosensors
Understand the concepts, types, working principles, and practical applications of significant biosensors
Explain the principles and mechanisms of inhibition-based biosensors

A.P.F. Turner, I. Karube, and G.S. Wilson, “Biosensors: Fundamentals and Applications”, Oxford University Press
referenceBooks: Ajit Sadana, “Engineering Biosensors: Kinetics and Design Applications”, Academic Press, San Diego

modules.title: Predictive Analytics and Simulation

modules.title: Prescriptive Analytics and Optimization
topics: Linear optimization: model formulation and solution techniques

Integer and nonlinear optimization: models with binary and integer variables

Optimization analytics and what-if analysis for optimization models

courseOutcomes: Understand the emergence of Business Analytics as a competitive strategy
Learn data visualization and effective storytelling through data
Apply descriptive analytics techniques and tools for business decision-making
Use predictive analytics methods to forecast and analyze data trends
Implement prescriptive analytics tools to optimize business processes
Analyze and solve problems across industries such as manufacturing, services, retail, banking, and finance

referenceBooks: U. Dinesh Kumar, “Business Analytics: The Science of Data-Driven Decision Making”, 2nd Edition, Wiley

modules.title: Introduction to Strategic Management
topics: Concept of strategy using case studies of business failure and turnaround success

courseName: Error Control Coding for Secure Data Transmission

modules.title: Information Theory and Source Coding
topics: Concept of uncertainty and information; measures of information
Self and conditional information, mutual information, and entropy
Fixed-length and variable-length codes; prefix and instantaneous codes
Kraft inequality and its significance in coding theory
Source coding theorem and the concept of efficient source coding
Huffman coding and Shannon–Fano coding methods
Arithmetic coding and Lempel–Ziv algorithm
Overview of communication channels: discrete memoryless channels and channel matrices
Types of channels: lossless, deterministic, and noiseless channels
Deterministic channel capacity, channel coding, information capacity theorem, and Shannon limit

modules.title: Block Codes and Linear Block Codes
topics: Introduction to block codes and their importance in error detection and correction

Generator and parity check matrices and their construction

modules.title: Cyclic Codes, Galois Fields, and BCH Codes
topics: Definition and properties of cyclic codes and their advantages

modules.title: Convolution Codes and Decoding Techniques

Structural properties: state diagrams, state tables, state transition tables

courseOutcomes: Calculate entropy, mutual information, and channel capacity for various types of communication channels
Analyze discrete memoryless channels using source and transition probabilities
Design and demonstrate encoders and decoders for linear block and cyclic codes
Apply modern linear algebra concepts to error control coding techniques

Develop an understanding of different types of coding methods used for secure data transmission

Ranjan Bose, “Information Theory, Coding and Cryptography”, TMH
N. Abramson, “Information and Coding”, McGraw Hill
referenceBooks: M. Mansurpur, “Introduction to Information Theory”, McGraw Hill

modules.title: Overview of AVR Microcontroller and Communication Interfaces
topics: Introduction to AVR (ATmega328p-pu) microcontroller: pin layout and architecture
Program memory and Data Direction Register (DDRx)
Port Registers (PORTx) and PWM registers (8-bit)
ADC registers and interrupt handling in AVR
Basics of communication interfaces: I2C Bus, UART, and SPI
Overview and interfacing of I/O devices using I2C Bus, UART, and SPI

modules.title: Embedded Operating Systems and Real-Time Concepts
topics: Basics of operating systems and types of operating systems
Concepts of tasks, processes, and threads
Multiprocessing and multitasking fundamentals
Task scheduling and its algorithms
Task communication methods: shared memory, message passing, remote procedure calls, and sockets
Task synchronization issues and techniques
Overview of device drivers and selection of a Real-Time Operating System (RTOS)

modules.title: Hardware Interfacing and Embedded Programming with ATmega328p
topics: Interfacing of LCD with ATmega328p
Interfacing with analog sensors: LM35 temperature sensor and ADXL 335 accelerometer
Interfacing of stepper motors and keyboard with AVR
Interfacing MPU6050 (MEMS accelerometer and gyroscope) using I2C bus
Programming and debugging techniques for hardware interfaces

courseOutcomes: Explain the definitions, components, and requirements of embedded systems
Acquire knowledge in embedded system design using AVR microcontrollers
Develop interfacing and communication techniques in embedded systems
Understand the basic concepts of Real-Time Operating Systems (RTOS)
Explain message passing and task synchronization techniques in embedded systems
Develop algorithms for real-time embedded applications
textBooks: Raj Kamal, “Embedded System: Architecture, Programming, Design”, McGraw Hill
Elliot Williams, “AVR Programming: Learning to Write Software for Hardware”, Maker Media Inc.

Dhananjay Gadre, “Programming and Customizing the AVR Microcontroller”, McGraw Hill Education

modules.title: Introduction to Industrial Sociology and Development of Industry
topics: Concept, scope, and significance of industrial sociology
The rise of industrial sociology: Hawthorne Experiment
Impact of industrial institutions on society
Caste and class conflict in industrial society
Development of industry in Western society: The Manorial System, Guild System, and Putting Out System
Factory System: characteristics and the factory as a social system
Industrial policy and labor legislation

modules.title: Organizational Structure of Industry and Trade Unions
topics: Formal organization: line and staff structure
Informal organization and industrial bureaucracy
Division of labor and its implications
Trade Union movements in India: history and growth
Recognition, election, affiliation, and social responsibilities of trade unions
Employers’ associations and their roles in industrial relations

modules.title: Industrial Relations and Legal Provisions
topics: Industrial development in India and characteristics of Indian labor
Labor problems and absenteeism in Indian industries
Social consequences of industrialism in India
Industrial Relations (IR) mechanisms: conciliation, arbitration, and adjudication
Collective bargaining: nature, processes, and issues
Tripartite consultation: statutory and non-statutory committees and boards
Legal provisions regarding strikes, lockouts, unfair labor practices, and recovery of dues

modules.title: Labor Laws and Labor Welfare
topics: Key provisions of major labor laws: Industrial Disputes Act (1947), Trade Unions Act (1926), Factories Act (1948), Employees State Insurance Act (1948)
Overview of new labor codes and their implications
Labor welfare concepts: industrial welfare and benefit administration
Social security measures and corporate social responsibility (CSR)
Role of welfare officers and welfare funds
Workers’ education and issues related to women and child labor

courseOutcomes: Critically understand the impact of industrial institutions on society
Implement sociological theories in an industrial context
Grasp the ideas of trade union movements and class conflicts in India
Understand the fundamentals of industrial relations and mechanisms for dispute resolution
Apply knowledge of labor laws and labor welfare in industrial settings
Effectively resolve industrial disputes using established legal and organizational tools
textBooks: Arun Monappa, “Industrial Relations and Labor Laws”, McGraw-Hill
Ashok Raj, “Industrial Sociology”, S.K. Kataria & Sons
referenceBooks: S.L. Aggarwal, “Labor Relations Law in India”, Macmillan
Sharmistha Bhattacharjee, “Industrial Sociology”, Pointer Publishers

modules.title: Introduction to Marketing and Market Segmentation
topics: Definitions and core concepts of marketing: need, want, demand, offering, branding, value, and satisfaction
Evolution of marketing concepts (orientations)
Marketing Mix – 4Ps (Product, Price, Place, Promotion) and 4Cs (Customer, Cost, Convenience, Communication)
Market Segmentation, Targeting, and Positioning (STP)
Bases of segmentation: geographic, demographic, psychographic (VALS-II), and behavioral
Targeting approaches: mass marketing, segment marketing, niche marketing, micro marketing, and customization
Concept of differentiation and positioning

modules.title: Consumer Behavior and Marketing Research
topics: Framework of consumer decision-making process
Major factors influencing consumer behavior
Marketing research: role and importance in managerial decision-making
Steps and process of marketing research
Introduction to B2B (Business-to-Business) marketing and its significance

modules.title: Product, Branding, and Packaging
topics: Product classification and service characteristics
Expanded service mix elements and product levels
Product mix and product line management
Product Life Cycle (PLC): concept, types, and strategies across PLC phases
New Product Development (NPD) process and innovation in product design
Branding: purpose, brand equity, and branding strategies
Packaging: purpose, types (primary, secondary, and shipping packages), and its role in marketing

modules.title: Pricing and Promotion Strategies
topics: Procedure for price setting and pricing objectives
Cost and demand considerations in pricing decisions
Pricing methods and strategies for different market conditions
Promotion mix elements: advertising, sales promotion, personal selling, direct marketing, publicity, and public relations
5M model of advertising (Mission, Money, Message, Media, Measurement)
Concept of digital marketing and overview of the selling process

courseOutcomes: Identify the scope and significance of marketing in the modern business environment
Practice effective marketing communication skills relevant to corporate settings
Coordinate various marketing environment variables and interpret them for designing marketing strategies
Illustrate marketing research skills to design innovative strategies for business firms
textBooks: Ramaswamy & Namakumari, “Marketing Management”, McMillan
Philip Kotler, Kevin Keller, Abraham Koshy, and Mithileshwar Jha, “Marketing Management”, Pearson
referenceBooks: R. Saxena, “Marketing Management”, TMH

modules.title: Introduction to Marketing Research and Research Process
topics: Meaning, definition, and scope of marketing research
Applications of research in managerial decision-making
Aims, roles, functions, and sources of research in business
Client–user interface: role conflict and resolution
Research process: steps in planning and execution
Formulating research purpose and objectives
Converting a manager’s problem into a researcher’s problem
Problem formulation, research design, data collection, analysis, and report presentation
Preparation and structure of a research proposal

modules.title: Research Design and Sources of Data
topics: Types of research design: exploratory, descriptive, and causal studies
Types of information: behavioral and non-behavioral correlates
Sources of data: primary and secondary (government, non-government, syndicated research)
Errors in data collection and their minimization
Role of research design in achieving reliability and validity

modules.title: Data Collection Methods, Measurement, and Scaling
topics: Primary data collection methods: focus groups, observations, case histories, and surveys
Survey methods: structured and unstructured, direct and indirect approaches
In-depth interviews, panels, and interview media (personal, telephone, internet, and mail)
Questionnaire construction and pre-testing
Qualitative vs. quantitative research techniques
Measurement and scaling: levels of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio scales
Attitude measurement: paired comparison, ranking, rating, and ordered category sorting methods
Quantitative judgment methods and their applications in marketing studies

modules.title: Sampling and Data Analysis Techniques
topics: Census vs. sampling: advantages and disadvantages

Types of sampling: probabilistic and non-probabilistic techniques
Determination of sample size and representativeness
Classification and coding of data for analysis
Analytical techniques: introduction to univariate and multivariate analysis
Overview of regression, discriminant, factor, cluster, multidimensional scaling, and conjoint analysis
Hypothesis testing and interpretation of results

courseOutcomes: Understand the fundamental principles, concepts, and measurement tools essential for planning and evaluating marketing research
Design a logical and systematic marketing research plan
Differentiate between qualitative and quantitative research techniques
Operationalize marketing concepts to develop testable research propositions
Conduct exploratory research and utilize secondary data to formulate research questions effectively

P. Green, D. Tull, and G. Albaum, “Research for Marketing Decisions”, PHI

topics: Introduction to Natural Language Processing: issues and strategies
Tools of NLP and linguistic organization
NLP as an application domain
Word classes and regular expressions
Chomsky hierarchy, context-free grammars (CFG), and parsing techniques

Parsing with finite state transducers (FST) and combinational rules

modules.title: Language Modeling and Part of Speech Tagging
topics: Unigram, Bigram, Trigram, and N-gram language models

Part of Speech (POS) tagging and morphology
Named Entity Recognition (NER) and Markov Models
Hidden Markov Models (HMM) and Viterbi algorithm for sequence labeling
Transformation-based tagging and accuracy measurement in tagging tasks

modules.title: Semantics and Lexical Semantics
topics: Representing meaning: unambiguous representation, canonical forms, and expressiveness
Meaning structure of language and semantic analysis
Role of NLP in Information Retrieval (IR) and its integration with Latent Semantic Analysis
Lexical semantics: lexemes, synonymy, hyponymy, and metonymy
WordNet and computational approaches to lexical semantics
Supervised and unsupervised methods in semantic processing

modules.title: Pragmatics and Natural Language Generation
topics: Information theory: entropy, cross-entropy, and information gain
Reference resolution and related phenomena
Syntactic and semantic constraints in pronoun resolution
Pronoun resolution algorithms and discourse coherence
Discourse structure and text coherence
Natural Language Generation: architecture and discourse planning
Text schemata and rhetorical relations in NLG
Resource-constrained word sense disambiguation (WSD)
Parsing ambiguous sentences and probabilistic parsing algorithms

courseOutcomes: Learn various models, methods, and algorithms of Natural Language Processing to build automation tools for speech recognition, machine translation, spam filtering, text classification, and spell checking
Understand and estimate the parameters of probabilistic models
Identify problems solvable in language automation environments and recognize tasks that are challenging for traditional statistical models
Compare various part-of-speech tagging algorithms
Understand linguistic phenomena and explore linguistic features relevant to NLP tasks
Identify research opportunities and prepare to conduct research in NLP or related fields

referenceBooks: James Allen, “Natural Language Understanding”, Benjamin/Cummings, 2nd Edition

modules.title: Introduction to Non-Conventional Energy Sources

Solar energy: solar energy balance and methods of electricity production

Wind energy: wind energy conversion systems and power generation
Calculations on wind turbine performance and design
Basics of hydrothermal energy and its conversion techniques

topics: Biomass as a renewable energy source: definition, types, and availability

topics: Fundamentals of biodiesel production and its importance

modules.title: Hydrogen Energy and Fuel Cells
topics: Hydrogen as a clean energy source: concepts and energy systems

Hydrogen production methods: electrolysis, thermochemical processes, and hydrogen generation from fossil fuel, biomass, and renewable sources
Combustion of fuels and related problem-solving
Hydrogen storage technologies: carbon materials, metal hydrides, chemical hydrides, and cryogenic storage
Hydrogen fuel cells: working principle, importance, and classification

courseOutcomes: Understand the concept and necessity of non-conventional energy as an alternative energy source
Comprehend and apply the concepts of solar and wind energy to design photovoltaic cells and wind turbines
Classify and design different biogas production processes
Design biodiesel production processes using trans-esterification techniques
Understand hydrogen energy as a clean fuel and characterize hydrogen production processes
Comprehend the importance and classification of hydrogen fuel cells

S. Sarkar, “Fuels and Combustion”, 2nd Edition, University Press
Donald L. Klass, “Biomass for Renewable Energy, Fuels and Chemicals”, Academic Press

modules.title: Introduction to Production and Operations Management
topics: Difference between manufacturing and service operations
Product-process matrix and capacity planning
Responsibilities of the production manager
Production as a coordination function
Production cycle and the concept of production planning and control (PPC)
Characteristics of manufacturing systems and their classification with examples
Differences between intermittent and continuous production systems

modules.title: Plant Location and Plant Layout
topics: Need for a good plant location and factors influencing plant location
Tangible and intangible factors in location decision-making
Economic survey and site selection techniques
Need for a good plant layout and its characteristics
Costs associated with plant layout design
Process layout vs. product layout and optimization in layout design
Designing process and product layouts
Assembly line balancing – concept and related problems
Concept of cellular manufacturing and its advantages

modules.title: Purchase and Inventory Management
topics: Purchase management: purchasing procedure, value analysis, vendor selection, negotiation, and make-or-buy decisions

Introduction to EOQ (Economic Order Quantity) and EBQ (Economic Batch Quantity)

Deterministic demand models: EOQ, continuous and periodic review inventory models

modules.title: Maintenance Management and Work Study
topics: Types of maintenance: breakdown and preventive maintenance

Basic procedure for performing work study
Method study: objectives, procedures, and documentation
Work measurement: objectives, procedures, and tools
Concepts of performance rating, basic time, allowances, and standard time calculation

courseOutcomes: Enhance analytical skills to support effective decision-making in operations management
Understand the strategic importance of operations management in achieving competitive advantage
Analyze the relationship between operations and other business functions in organizations
Apply techniques for facility location, layout planning, line balancing, and job scheduling
Implement material and inventory management concepts including demand management and classification systems

modules.title: Introduction, Learning, Attitude, and Personality

Nature and theories of learning: conditioning, shaping, and reinforcement

modules.title: Motivation, Perception, and Decision Making

Decision-making models: Rational Model, Bounded Rationality, and Intuition

modules.title: Emotions, Group Behavior, and Leadership
topics: Emotions and moods: functions, sources, and organizational relevance

Group properties, groupthink, and groupshift

Centralization, decentralization, and formalization

Organizational development interventions and processes
Work stress: sources, effects, and management techniques
Conflict: traditional and interactionist views, conflict process, and negotiation strategies
Introduction to power and politics in organizations

courseOutcomes: Understand the basic concepts of Organizational Behavior and its applications in contemporary organizations
Recognize how individuals, groups, and structures influence organizational effectiveness and efficiency
Appreciate the major theories and models related to organizational behavior
Apply innovative and creative approaches to solve organizational challenges
Value diversity and cultural differences in the workplace
Manage and cope effectively with organizational changes, stress, and power politics

Luthans, “Organizational Behavior”, McGraw Hill
referenceBooks: Amy C. Edmondson, “The Fearless Organization”, Wiley

Analyze genetic algorithms and their applications in optimization problems
Demonstrate various neural network architectures, algorithms, applications, and limitations
Apply fuzzy sets, fuzzy rules, fuzzy inference systems, and approximate reasoning techniques
